content.description: The crux is in the thin seem about halfway up the rock. Make some 5.8 moves to the crux and finish with more 5.8 moves to the anchors.  It is a really, really fun climb.
content.protection: Small, to medium cams.  The anchors at top are in good condition.
content.location:
It is about a hundred and fifty feet to the right as you're facing the wall from

the 5.9+

.  Walk past a sport route bolted on an arete, then past a random crack with a piece of gear, and find the anchors at the top of a great arete.

content.description: This is number 17 in the book. It is a fun and clean handcrack in a right-facing corner that goes from wide hands to thin hands as you climb. This is surprisingly steep through the first 20 feet.
content.protection: Bring cams from 0.75 to 3.  It has a 1 bolt anchor with a leaver biner. Consider equalizing with a #1 cam at the anchor if setting up a toprope.
content.location: It is fairly far to the climber's right down the cliff. This is in a right-facing corner to the left of a giant block leaning into the cliff. The climber's trail goes under this block.

content.description: This is route #18 in the book. It is an obvious, vertical, wide crack on low angle rock. There is a bit of lichen and some OW sections.
content.protection:
Bring a standard rack up to OW if you need it.  It has a 2 bolt anchor in the black, varnished rock.

We climbed on a 70m and it got us down fine. A 60m might not do it.
content.location:
It is a 10-15 minute walk to climber's right from the trail up. It is a few minutes past

Unknown #7

(route 17 in the book).

content.description: This is a great route on solid rock with an excellent roof!
content.protection: Climb fingers to hands with a #3 Camalot past the roof. There are anchors right above roof. It looks like you could keep going to a possible second set of anchors higher up.
content.location: The route is on the prow of the buttress going through a 6 foot roof.

content.description: This is a great climb! Climb fingers to a good rest, then splitter hands that widen as you go until the anchors. It has fun moves the whole way through.  This is #21 in the guidebook.
content.location:
It is the last climb on the buttress. It is maybe a 5 minute walk right of

Angel of Harlem

and 100 feet right of a 5.9 crack with a bush about ten feet up.

content.description: Climb up the THIN finger crack in a left-facing flare. A few blocks are stacked at the bottom of this one so shorter folk can reach the first lock. Use stem tech wizardry to make it through this one!
content.protection: Doubles in small gear from BD 00 to BD 0.5. We placed nothing bigger than a #0.5 BD, but you could bring a #3 to protect the last move.
content.location: This is just up and right of where the main trail meets the wall. The main trail starts across the road from the 95 mile marker.

content.description:
Start up laybacking up with face holds on both sides of the corner until it pinches shut and a long reach gets you to the anchors.

Per

Paul Byrne

: This is a short, fun, finger crack in a right-facing corner. It has great finger locks and face footholds for liebacking. This is easier than it looks, and the gear placements are as straightforward as it gets.
content.protection:
Rack some fingers to a #3.

Per

Paul Byrne

: Bring a handful of finger-sized pieces, nothing bigger than a #0.5 Camalot (purple).
content.location:
It is one route to climber's right past

Coyote Ugly, et al.

.

Per

Paul Byrne

: Climb right of a route through a roof with a bolt protecting it and right of a thin finger crack in a left-facing flare. It is a a few minute walk climber's right of the trail up to the wall.

content.description: Great route with an awesome move through the roof. Changing corners into a dark, looming, offwidth roof into a fist crack. We thought the crux was after the roof climbing and laybacking through #3.5 to #4 size.
content.protection: There is a bolt at the end of the roof. Bring gear: single 0.5 and 0.75, doubles in 1, 2, 3.5, and 4, and a single 6 for the roof.
content.location:
It is left of the corner route '

My Pet Goat

'. Once at wall from the trail, walk right for ~100 feet.

content.description: Start in a left-facing corner that changes to a right-facing corner, and go through the sizes from fingers to some cupped hands!

climbs.name: Lithium (Evan's Offwidth)
climbs.fa: Evan Deis, David Hoven, Spencer Cone, Sam Andree

content.description:
P1 is phenomenal. The climbing here is of the highest quality. Both of the cruxes are short and well-protected (as long as you don't run out of #6s). Do this pitch! A three bolt anchor makes it easy to set this up as a toprope.

If you choose to sally onward, P2 follows an aid seam up a thin dihedral to the base of the roof. Bring small stoppers and tiny cams for the crux. A two bolt anchor lies below the roof. C1+

P3 traverses under the roof on a sandy crack with mega exposure! Although the rock quality deteriorates slightly, the roof is easily aided at C1. Do not turn the corner after the roof as there is a death block above. Instead, keep following the horizontal crack as it widens to 5.10 hands and ends at a stance where a gear anchor can be erected. It is conceivable that a stronger fellow than I could free this entire pitch at 5.11 or 5.12.

P4 is a scramble to the summit.

To descend, make a short rap off a slung tree to another, larger ledge. On the South side of this ledge you can find the anchors and rappel line for Dairygold.
content.protection: Small stoppers, doubles from #0.2 to 5, and three #6s for P1. There are bolted anchors at the top of P1 and P2.
content.location: Head up the trail from CO 141. Lithium begins with the spectacular offwidth to the left of the other routes here.

content.description:
This is a great climb on some good rock with a little bit of lichen. There is a little bit of everything, the crux being the #0.75 section.

Per

Paul Byrne

: This is number 8 in the guidebook. It is a lichen covered, right-facing corner. There are lots of good jams and pods. It is a good warmup.
content.protection:
Singles to thin fingers, doubles through big fingers and hands.

Per

Paul Byrne

: Bring a standard rack. There is a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is one route to the climber's left of

Coyote Ugly, et al.

.

Per

Paul Byrne

: Go up the path from mile marker 95 and a short walk to climber's right. This is left of an obvious, wide hands splitter.

climbs.name: Dairygold
climbs.fa: Dave Hoven, Dan Swansinger, Kevin Vanharn, 2014

content.description:
Dairygold is excellent in general with a fantastic 3rd pitch. It is mostly hand-size crack climbing with a little groveling here and there.

P1. Begin on a shelf at the base of the obvious dihedral. Climb fingers/hands/fist/OW through mediocre rock to a 2 bolt anchor on the left. When we first climbed this, we found a large hex fixed about 2/3 of the way up the pitch; however, there were no anchors at the obvious finish. I'd love to credit whoever first climbed the initial 50 feet of the route - if anyone has info, please let me know. The first pitch is worthwhile if just cragging, 75 feet, 5.10.

P2. Traverse left and up across the slab to a sloping ledge. This requires about 35 feet of easy but unprotected climbing. From the sloping ledge, climb a loose offwidth/chimney 20 feet to a 2 bolt anchor on a nice pedestal, 60 feet, 5.8.

P3. Climb 10 feet up the finger crack in the dihedral, then work left into the splitter hand crack on the face. Continue up 80 feet of heavenly crack climbing. At the top of the pitch, work right to find 3 bolts in good rock at a large ledge, 90 feet, 5.10.

P4 (optional). Climb 5.5 to the next ledge, then scramble to a massive block on the rim - there are amazing views from the top. There's a sling on a tree to help with the descent.

The best way to descend is to make a single rope rappel from the top of P3 to the top of P2, then do a double rope rappel to the ground.
content.protection: All the anchors are bolted. Bring a standard rack with several extra BD #2 sizes and perhaps an extra #1 and #3. A #4 for P1 is nice.
content.location: The route is located around the prow to the left (South) of the main cragging area. From the obvious roof crack that splits the prow, scramble left and up about 100 feet. One can easily traverse a ledge to the proper base of the P1 dihedral. The splitter that makes the 3rd pitch can be seen from the road.

content.description: This is a striking splitter that starts off wide hands and goes to fists through a small roof. Keep plugging to the anchors.
content.location: The route is a few hundred yards up canyon towards Gateway. It is the obvious, clean looking, wide splitter.

content.description: This goes up a short, steep section of funky climbing in a right-facing corner/flake to a long, left-leaning flake system. The gear is a bit funky as much of it is flaring and hollow sounding. It is pretty messy with loose rock and lichen.
content.protection: Bring a standard rack from fingers to #4 Camalot.  It has a 2 bolt anchor to the left of a small roof. With the traversing terrain, a 60m may not get you down.
content.location:
This is climber's right of

Stepping Stone

in a right-facing corner/flake system.

pathTokens: Gateway Vicinity aka The West End
